questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with injury to the medial epicondyle of the humerus. Which of the following is least likely to be seen?

choices.text: Weakness of the ulnar deviation and flexion
Complete paralysis of the IIIrd and IVth digits
Decreased sensation of the hypothenar eminence

questions.solution:
Injury to the medial epicondyle injures the ulnar nerve. Since flexor digitorum superficialis (supplied by median nerve) and extensor digitorum (supplied by the radial nerve) are still functional, complete paralysis of the third and fourth digits is not seen. 

Injury to the medial epicondyle damages the ulnar nerve. This causes:

  • Paralysis of:
    • Flexor carpi ulnaris (FCU) - loss of ulnar deviation 
    • Medial half of flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) - loss of distal interphalangeal joint flexion
    • Hypothenar paralysis - lead to atrophy
  • Sensory loss over medial 1/3 of hand and medial 1 1/2 fingers

questions.text: The hormone secreted by the acidophil cells of the anterior pituitary apart from prolactin is ______
questions.solution:
GH and prolactin are both secreted by the acidophil cells of the anterior pituitary. They act on cytokine receptors and show JAK-STAT activity, and hence are called twin hormones.

Related Pearl: Cells of Anterior Pituitary

questions.text: Which of the following molecular analysis methods is used to detect RNA?
questions.solution:
RT PCR (Reverse Transcriptase PCR) is a molecular analysis method used for the detection of RNA. It can be used to quantitate mRNA levels by generating complementary DNA (cDNA) copies of the mRNA using the reverse transcriptase enzyme. 

The northern blot technique can also be used to detect RNAs. Here, the mixture of mRNA molecules is separated by electrophoresis and then transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane and hybridized with radiolabeled probes.

Sanger’s technique:

  • This was the first technique used to determine the sequence of proteins.
  • Sanger’s reagent is 1- Flouro 2,4 Dinitro benzene.
  • The first protein to be sequenced by this method was insulin.

G banding (Giemsa banding):

It is the most common technique used in cytogenetics to produce a visible karyotype by staining condensed chromosomes. It is useful for identifying genetic diseases through the photographic representation of the entire chromosome complement. The metaphase chromosomes are treated with trypsin (to partially digest the chromosome) and stained with Giemsa stain. 

Heterochromatic regions, which tend to be rich with adenine and thymine (AT-rich) DNA and relatively gene-poor, stain darker and appear as dark bands in G-banding. In contrast, less condensed chromatin, which tends to be rich with guanine and cytosine (GC-rich) and more transcriptionally active incorporates less Giemsa stain, and these regions appear as light bands in G-banding. The image below shows a G-banding karyogram of a normal human male.

Western blot, also called immunoblots, is a technique used to study protein molecules. The proteins undergo electrophoresis and then are transferred to a membrane. These proteins are then tagged with the specific antibodies and visualized.

questions.text:
Arrange the following cellular events of inflammation in the correct sequence:
  1. Rolling
  2. Cytokine mediated integrin activation
  3. Adhesion
  4. Migration
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of cellular events that occur during inflammation is:

  • Rolling
  • Cytokine mediated integrin activation
  • Adhesion
  • Migration

The recruitment of leukocytes to the site of inflammation is a multi-step process, that is mediated by adhesion molecules and cytokines called chemokines. This process can be divided into sequential phases:

  1. In the lumen: margination, rolling and adhesion to the endothelium occurs.
  2. Migration of the leukocytes across the endothelium and vessel wall
  3. Migration in the tissues towards a chemotactic stimulus.

The process of leukocyte recruitment is as follows:

  • Margination: Because of dilation of the inflamed postcapillary venues, there is stasis of blood flow and hence more leukocytes assume a peripheral position along the endothelial surface; this process of leukocyte redistribution is called margination.
  • Rolling: the slowed leukocytes then sense the signals from the endothelium and start rolling on the vessel wall.
  • Cytokine-mediated integrin activation: the attachment of leukocytes to the endothelial cells requires adhesion molecules that are activated by cytokines. The major families of proteins involved in adhesion and migration are selectins and integrins and their ligands.
  • Adhesions: the weak rolling interactions slow down the leukocytes and allow them to bind more firmly to the endothelium. Chemokines that were produced at the site of injury bind to the endothelial cell proteoglycans. These chemokines then bind to the rolling leukocytes and activate them. This is turn converts the ligands for β1 and β2 integrins, VLA-4 and LFA-1 present on the leukocytes to a high-affinity state.
  • This combination of cytokine-induced expression of integrin ligands on the endothelium and increased integrin affinity on the leukocytes leads to firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium at the site of inflammation.
  • Leukocyte migration: this is the movement of leukocytes through intact endothelium, called transmigration or diapedesis. This occurs in postcapillary venules. This migration occurs through the inter endothelial gap towards the chemical concentration gradient created by the chemokines at the site of injury. This occurs with the help of adhesion molecules present in the intercellular junctions such as Platelet Endothelial Cell Adhesion Molecule (PECAM-1) or CD31.

questions.text: What is the method of choice for the diagnosis of kala-azar?
questions.solution:
The rapid dipstick test is the method of choice for the diagnosis of kala-azar.

The following tests are used for the laboratory diagnosis of kala-azar:

  • Rapid diagnostic tests - rK39 and dipstick test strip.
  • Parasitological diagnosis - demonstration of LD bodies on microscopy is confirmatory
  • Surveillance purposes - Aldehyde test of Napier
  • Serological diagnosis - Rapid dipstick test, direct agglutination test, ELISA, indirect fluorescent antibody test
  • Assessing immune status - Leishmanin (Montenegro) test 
    • Induration of ≥ 5 mm is considered positive
    • Usually becomes positive 4-6 weeks after onset of cutaneous leishmaniasis

questions.text: A 55-year-old man admitted with ischemic stroke was given IV alteplase. After 8 hours, the ICU staff noticed decreasing mental status and acute hypertension in the patient. A repeat CT revealed the following, Which of the following drugs can be used to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of post-thrombolytic hemorrhagic transformation of an ischemic stroke. ε-Aminocaproic acid can be used as an antidote for fibrinolytic therapy.

It is a lysine analog that binds competitively to plasminogen, blocking plasminogen from binding to fibrin and the subsequent conversion to plasmin. This activity subsequently results in the inhibition of fibrinolysis.

It should not be given unless hemorrhage is life-threatening because it inhibits intrinsic fibrinolytic activity and can precipitate DIC. Fresh frozen plasma and cryoprecipitate may also be used to replenish fibrin and clotting factors.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 33-year-old patient, you notice the following finding shown in the image. This is characteristic of :
questions.solution:
The image shows Burtonian lines, seen in lead poisoning. With long term-exposure, patients of lead poisoning can develop bluish-gray gingival lead lines (called Burtonian lines).

Burtonian lines can also be seen in mercury poisoning.

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

 Features Lead
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action

binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits

  • ALA dehydratase
  • ferrochelatase

inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase

competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract

Bone marrow

Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS

Renal
Characteristic clinical findings

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the ENT surgeon with a history of vertigo whenever she moves sideways on the bed while lying supine. She feels nauseous and as if the room is spinning. The symptoms subside after a few minutes but return when she moves her head. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The diagnostic maneuver used in BPPV is the Dix-Hallpike maneuver, the gold standard for diagnosing BPPV. The therapeutic maneuver is Epley's maneuver.

BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal.

A patient presenting with vertigo should be evaluated for ruling out the central lesions (like a tumor in the fourth ventricle, multiple sclerosis, etc) before confirming the diagnosis of BPPV. Dix-Hallpike maneuver helps rule out central lesions and also diagnose BPPV.

Dix-Hallpike maneuver:

  1. The maneuver starts with the patient in a sitting position.
  2. Their head is turned 45 degrees towards the ear to be tested.
  3. The examiner quickly brings the patient to a supine position with their head 30 degrees below the horizontal.
  4. The 45-degree head rotation is maintained during the procedure.
  5. Now the examiner observes the patient for nystagmus.

questions.text: Oil droplet cataract is seen in ______________.
questions.solution:
Oil droplet cataract is seen in galactosemia.

Other options:

  • Diabetes: Snow-flake cataract
  • Wilson’s disease: Sunflower cataract
  • Homocystinuria: Bilateral inferonasal subluxation of the lens

questions.text: All the following are notifiable occupational diseases under the Factories act except ____________.
questions.solution:
Bagassosis is not a notifiable disease.

Related Pearl: Notifiable occupational diseases

 

There are 29 diseases notifiable to the government under Indian Factory Act 1948, some important ones are

  • Byssinosis
  • Asbestosis
  • Anthracosis
  • Noise induced hearing loss
  • Occupational dermatitis
  • Occupational cancers
  • Silicosis

questions.text: In a population of 5000, new cases of TB are 500 and old cases are 150. What is the prevalence of TB in this case?
questions.solution:
The prevalence of TB is 13%.

The calculation is as follows:

  1. The total number of cases at the given time is 500 new cases + 150 old cases, which equals 650
  2. The total number of cases is divided by the total population which is 5000 
  3. The percentage is calculated by multiplying with 100

Thus, prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

Incidence in Epidemiology:

  • Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time.
  • Incidence = (Number of cases of a disease in a specified period of time/Population at risk during that time) x 1000
  • Incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year.
  • It provides insight into the effectives of health services and programs.
  • Incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000
  • It is generally used for acute illnesses.
  • Special types of incidence rates:
    • Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.
    • Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.
  • Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

Prevalence in Epidemiology:

  • Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population.
  • It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio.
  • It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.
  • Types:
    • Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.
    • Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.
  • Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.
  • Prevalence = (Number of all cases of a specified disease at a given point in time/Estimated population at the same point in time) x 100
  • It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

  • Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.
  • Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration
  • Longer the duration of the disease, greater the prevalence.
  • In acute diseases,because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence.This is because in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as duration of disease decreases.
  • If treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: A newly diagnosed HIV patient presented with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. His sputum sample showed acid-fast bacilli. What is the appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Start ART and then ATT after 2 weeks
Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks

questions.solution:
In a patient with HIV and TB start ATT first and then start ART as soon as ATT is tolerated (between 2 weeks and 2 months) by the patient. This is done in order to avoid immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). 

Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS):

Patients with HIV-related TB may experience a temporary paradoxical exacerbation of symptoms and radiographic manifestations of TB after starting ATT. This occurs as a result of immune reconstitution due to simultaneous administration of ART and ATT.

It is characterized by high fever, lymphadenopathy, expanding intra-thoracic lesions, and worsening of chest x-ray findings. Diagnosis should be made only after ruling out treatment failure and other infections. For severe cases, prednisone 1-2mg/kg is used for 1-2 weeks and then gradually tapered.

However, in patients with CD4 <50/μL, the benefits of administering ART immediately after initiating ATT outweigh the risks of IRIS, and therefore ART should be started as early as possible.

Note: As per RNTCP guidelines, CBNAAT is the preferred diagnostic technique for testing TB in PLHIV (people living with HIV). Smear microscopy has poor sensitivity in detecting TB in PLHIV due to fewer organisms in sputum, and hence is not preferred.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a risk factor for severe illness in a patient with COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Young age is not a risk factor for severe illness in a patient with COVID-19.

Although severe illness can occur in otherwise healthy individuals of any age, it predominantly occurs in adults with advanced age or underlying medical comorbidities. The comorbidities associated with severe illness and mortality include:

  • Cardiovascular disease
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypertension
  • Chronic lung disease
  • Cancer
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • Obesity (body mass index ≥30)
  • Smoking

Immunosuppression is also presumed to be a risk factor for severe illness and mortality, but this has not yet been definitively demonstrated in studies.

questions.text: Which type of aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus?
questions.solution:
Wernicke's aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus due to the involvement of the Wernicke's area. The speech is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense.

Other options: 

Option B- Broca's or motor/non-fluent aphasia is seen in lesions of the inferior frontal gyrus which contains the motor speech area. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted, with a paucity of functional words.

Option C- Comprehension of written language and the ability to name objects are compromised in anomic aphasia. This aphasia is caused by damage to the angular gyrus that disrupts visual information processing and transmission to the Wernicke area.

Option D- Conduction aphasia is seen in lesions of the arcuate fasciculus, the bundle of nerve fibers connecting the Wernicke and Broca's areas. Repetition of words is impaired and paraphasias are observed, though not as much as in Wernicke aphasia.

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

  Wernicke's Broca's Global Conduction Anterior (nonfluent) transcortical Posterior (fluent) transcortical Isolation Anomic Pure Word Deafness Pure Alexia
Comprehension Impaired Preserved Impaired Preserved Preserved Impaired Impaired Preserved Impaired only for spoken language Impaired only for reading
Repetition of Spoken language Impaired Impaired Impaired Impaired Preserved Preserved Echolalia Preserved Impaired Preserved
Naming Impaired Impaired Impaired Impaired Impaired Impaired Impaired Impaired Preserved Preserved 
Fluency Preserved Decreased Decreased Preserved Impaired Preserved No purposeful speech Preserved except for word finding pauses Preserved Preserved

questions.text: Gold standard diagnostic test in varicose vein is ______
questions.solution:
Gold standard test for varicose veins is duplex ultrasound.

The aim of the duplex scan in patients with varicose veins is to establish:

  • Which saphenous junctions are incompetent and their locations.
  • Extent of reflux in the saphenous veins and their diameters.
  • Number, location, and diameter of incompetent perforating veins; other relevant veins that demonstrate reflux.
  • Source of all superficial varices if not from the veins already described.
  • Competence and evidence of previous venous thrombosis in the deep venous system.

 

Mickey Mouse sign is seen in transverse B mode image doppler ultrasound formed by:

  • Common Femoral Vein (CFV)
  • Common Femoral Artery (CFA)
  • Greater Saphenous Vein (GSV) at the Saphenofemoral junction (SFJ).

It represents the normal anatomy of the femoral vessels as seen in duplex ultrasound.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Revised Trauma Score ?
questions.solution:
Pulse rate is not a component of Revised Trauma Score.

Glasgow coma scale, Respiratory rate and Systolic BP are components of Revised Trauma Score (0-12).

Various scoring systems are used to score the trauma are :

  • AIS – Abbreviated Injury Scale
  • ISS – Injury Severity Score
  • OIS – Organ Injury Scale
  • GCS – Glasgow Coma Scale
  • RTS – Revised Trauma Score
  • MESS – Mangled Extremity Severity Score
  • TRISS – Trauma and Injury Severity Score

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
1-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: During a cricket match, a batsman controls his urge to urinate as he is unable to take a break in-between. While batting, he suffers a sudden blow as the ball hits him in the suprapubic region. He presents to the emergency department with severe hypogastric pain and the inability to pass urine. He collapses suddenly during the examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Pubic diastasis with bulbar urethra rupture

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of injury to a full bladder, inability to pass urine, and syncope are suggestive of intraperitoneal rupture of the bladder.

Bladder rupture can be of two types:

  Extraperitoneal rupture Intraperitoneal rupture
  More common (80%)  Less common (20%)
Cause
  • Penetrating trauma
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Surgical damage
  • Associated with proximal urethral injury
  
  • Direct blow or fall on a distended bladder
Clinical features
  • Pelvic urinoma (encapsulated collection of extravasated urine) is seen
  • Blood at the tip of the meatus
  • Sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium
  • Syncope
  • Peritonitis
 
Treatment
  • Catheter drainage for 7–10 days
  • Laparotomy
  • Repair of bladder
  • Bladder drainage
 


Pubic diastasis refers to the separation of the pubic symphysis without concomitant fracture. Pubic diastasis with bulbar urethra rupture usually occurs due to straddle injury and presents with blood at the tip of the meatus.

questions.text:
According to IADPSG, what is the cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus?

IADPSG- International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Group
questions.solution:
According to IADPSG, the cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is >92 mg/dl.

Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM) refers to any degree of glucose intolerance having its onset or first recognition during pregnancy. 

For IADPSG criteria, an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is done in the fasting state using 75 g of glucose, and gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is diagnosed if any one of the following cut-offs is met i.e.

  • Fasting: >92 mg/dl 
  • 1 hour: >180 mg/dl  
  • 2 hour: >153 mg/dl

Earlier, a two-step approach was being used to diagnose GDM. In this, the first step (screening) is a 50-gram one-hour glucose challenge test (GCT). The patients having a positive result of >140mg/dl, are candidates for the OGTT. A 100-gram, three-hour oral glucose tolerance test (GTT), is the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus. GDM is diagnosed if two or more values are positive.

Diabetes in Pregnancy Societies of India(DIPSI) recommends a 1-step procedure with 75 g oral glucose without regard to the time of the last meal. A venous plasma glucose value at 2 hours >140 mg/dL is diagnosed as GDM.

Some complications of GDM include:

  • Maternal
    • Hypertension, preeclampsia
    • Hydramnios
    • Increased operative interventions
    • Future development of diabetes mellitus
  • Fetal and neonatal
    • Fetal macrosomia
    • Congenital anomalies
    • Metabolic abnormalities such as hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, hyperbilirubinemia, and neonatal hypoglycemia.
    • Respiratory distress syndrome
    • Subsequent childhood and adolescent obesity

 

Screening is usually done at 24-28 weeks of gestation. Early diagnosis and treatment are important to prevent complications.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of rectovaginal fistula?
questions.solution:
Improper suturing of complete perineal tears is the most common cause of rectovaginal fistula.

Rectovaginal fistulas occur most commonly due to obstetric causes such as perineal tears, obstructed labor, and instrumental deliveries. Other causes include:

  • Tuberculosis
  • Lymphogranuloma venerum
  • Bartholinitis - rupture of an abscess into the rectum can cause a fistula
  • Diverticulitis 
  • Carcinoma cervix
  • Radiotherapy - can cause ulceration which can develop into a fistula

questions.text:
The risk of cancer that can be reduced with OCP use are all, except?

OCP- Oral contraceptive pills
questions.solution:
Oral contraceptive pills (OCP) are not protective against breast cancer.

OCPs have no effect on the incidence of Breast Cancer.

OCPs protect against ovarian cancer (Option A). Oral contraceptives cause prolonged suppression of gonadotropin stimulation of ovary on long term use. This may account for lower incidence of ovarian malignancy noted in contraceptive users.

Other benefits of oral contraceptive pills:

  • Lesser incidence of endometrial carcinoma due to progestin component in OCP (Option D).
  • Regularisation of menstrual cycles results in relief of dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia.
  • Reduced incidence and relief of fibrocystic breast disease and ovarian cysts.
  • Endometriosis and pelvic inflammatory disease are improved.

questions.text: A karyotyping image is given below. What are the clinical features most likely to be expected in such patients?
questions.solution:
The given karyotyping image shows ‘47, XXY’ abnormality, which is seen in Klinefelter’s syndrome. Gynecomastia and long limbs are seen in Klinefelter's syndrome.

Other clinical features seen in Klinefelter’s syndrome are: 

  • Disproportionately long arms and legs,
  • Gynecomastia
  • Eunuchoid body habitus
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Mental retardation; IQ: 60-80,
  • Minor developmental and learning disabilities,
  • Lack of secondary sexual characteristics (due to a decrease in androgen production)
  • Higher risk of breast carcinoma
  • Testicular dysgenesis with small penis
  • Infertility/azoospermia
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus
  • Metabolic syndrome
  • Higher risk of extragonadal germ cell tumors

Klinefelter syndrome:

  • Most common sex aneuploidy in males
  • Classically karyotype is 47, XXY. Other variants can have 48 XXXY; rarely, 49 XXXXY; or mosaics with some cells containing normal 46, XY and others 47, XXY
  • Results from meiotic nondisjunction of sex chromosomes (mostly during 1st meiotic division)

Note:

A variant of Klinefelter’s syndrome—49, XXXXY—presents with short stature

Other options:

Option B: Flat occiput:

Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) is characterized by intellectual disability and distinctive physical features including a round face with flat occiput, protruding tongue, and flat nasal bridge. Characteristic facial features include oblique palpebral fissures (mongoloid slant), epicanthal folds, Brushfield's spots, and low-set dysplastic ears. Notable hand and foot abnormalities include incurved/short fifth finger with clinodactyly, simian palmar crease, and a sandal gap between the first and second toes.

Option C: Turner syndrome (45,XO) is characterized by webbing of neck and lymphedema. Short stature, short fourth metacarpal, sensorineural hearing loss, and shield chest deformity are also seen. Patients present with primary amenorrhea, infertility, and absent Barr body. The condition features distinctive cardiovascular defects, cubitus valgus, and congenital lymphedema. Reproductive abnormalities include underdeveloped streak ovaries with increased risk of gonadoblastoma if Y chromosome material is present. Additional characteristic features include webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, and horseshoe kidneys.

Option D: Patau syndrome (trisomy 13) is characterized by short stature and polydactyly, along with distinctive craniofacial features including midline cleft lip, ocular hypotelorism, bulbous nose, and low-set malformed ears. The syndrome presents with significant neurological involvement (microcephaly, holoprosencephaly), ocular defects (microphthalmia), and multiple systemic manifestations including cardiac malformations, scalp defects, skeletal abnormalities (hypoplastic/absent ribs), and visceral/genital anomalies. These severe malformations typically result in profound developmental delay and limited survival.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a radiological finding of left heart failure?
questions.solution:
Focal oligemia is not a radiological feature of left heart failure. Also known as Westermark's sign, it is seen in pulmonary embolism.

Radiological signs of left heart failure include :

  • Cardiomegaly - enlargement of the cardiac silhouette
  • Kerley B lines - horizontal lines in the periphery of the lower posterior lung fields
  • upper lobe pulmonary venous congestion 
  • interstitial edema.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with mood lability, sadness, and tearfulness 5 days after delivery. She has no thoughts of harming the baby. There is no history of previous mood disorders. There is no family history of mood disorders. What is the preferred treatment for her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of postpartum blues and the preferred treatment is supportive therapy.

Mild depressive symptoms after a few days of delivery which resolve spontaneously are characteristic of postpartum blues.

During this period the patient may experience mood lability, sadness, dysphoria, subjective confusion, and tearfulness. These feelings have been ascribed to rapid changes in women's hormonal levels, the stress of childbirth, and the awareness of the increased responsibility that motherhood brings. This usually resolves spontaneously. 

If the symptoms persist longer than two weeks, evaluation is indicated for postpartum depression.

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 12 weeks from delivery and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

 0.1-0.2% Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for rescue analgesia?
questions.solution:
Fentanyl is the drug of choice for providing rescue analgesia.

Rescue analgesia involves the use of medications to minimize post-operative pain. Mild pain can be controlled with oral analgesics but severe pain requires opioids like fentanyl.

Fentanyl is preferred over morphine or oxycodone due to its rapid onset of action, lesser incidence of postoperative nausea, vomiting, and other adverse effects.

questions.text: Extracorporeal photopheresis is used in the management of which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Extracorporeal photopheresis is a systemic therapy  used for mycosis fungoides.

  • The choice of initial treatment for the Mycosis fungoides patient will depend on the stage of the disease as well as the patient’s performance status.
  • Skin-Directed Therapy is preferred in the early stages whereas advanced stages requires systemic therapy.

The various treatment modalities available for treatment of Mycosis fungoides is given below.

Skin-Directed Therapy Systemic Therapy
  • Topical Corticosteroids
  • Topical Chemotherapy: nitrogen mustard (mechlorethamine) and carmustine (BCNU)
  • Topical rexinoids
  • Phototherapy and photochemotherapy (PUVA)
  • Radiotherapy and electron beam therapy (Mycosis fungoides and variants are highly radiosensitive)
  • Immunotherapy: Pegylated IFN‐α
  • Oral Retinoids and rexinoids
  • Combination therapy
  • Systemic chemotherapy
  • Extracorporeal photopheresis (ECP)
  • Toxin therapies: Denileukin diftitox
  • Monoclonal antibody therapy
  • Histone deacetylase inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about the device shown in the image below?

choices.text: Smaller ones are given to PHCs and the larger ones to district vaccine stores
They have temperature zones for different vaccines
Kata thermometer is used to record temperature inside this device
These devices are provided with baskets to store vaccines

questions.solution:
The image shown in the question is of an ice-lined refrigerator (ILR). Dial or digital thermometers are used to record temperatures inside an ice-lined refrigerator.

ILRs are the main method of vaccine storage in primary health centers. They are an important part of the cold chain and they maintain a temperature of 2 to 8 °C for the storage of vaccines.

They have different temperature zones for different vaccines. The upper zone is for freeze-sensitive vaccines like cholera, hep B, rotavirus(liquid), etc while the lower zone is for heat-sensitive vaccines like OPV, measles, etc.

All vaccines are kept in the basket provided with ILR. Vaccines like OPV, BCG, measles, and JE can be kept at the bottom of the basket while, DPT, TT, Hep B, IPV, and pentavalent vaccines and diluents are kept in the upper part of the basket. 

Related Pearl: Cold Chain Equipment

Cold chain equipment : 

Storage : 

  • Walk in cooler (WIC)
  • Walk in freezer (WIF)
  • Ice lined refrigerator (ILR)
  • Deep freezer 
  • Domestic refrigerator 

Solar :

  • Solar Refrigerator Battery drive
  • Solar Refrigerator Direct drive

Non electrical :

  • Cold box
  • Vaccine carrier

Transportation : 

  • Refrigerator vaccine van
  • Insulated vaccine van
  • Cold box 
  • Vaccine carrier

 

Electrical Cold Chain Equipment: 

Component

Temperature (degree Celsius)

Level

Other Comments

Walk in Freezers (WIF)

-15 to -25 

National, State and Regional vaccine stores

Used for bulk storage of OPV

Walk in Coolers (WIC)

+2 to +8

Government Medical Store Depot (GMSD), State and Regional vaccines stores

Used for bulk storage of most vaccines in UIP

Deep Freezer (DF)

-15 to -25 

District and Sub-district vaccines stores

Used for bulk storage of OPV and ice packs

Ice Line Refrigerator (ILR)

+2 to +8

District and Sub-district vaccines stores, PHCs

Has different temperature zones for different vaccines

Front Load Refrigerator (Domestic)

+2 to +8

Sub-district levels, hospitals. dispensaries and nursing homes

Used for all vaccines

questions.text: The arterial blood gas findings of a patient are pH = 7.12, pCO2 = 50, HCO3 = 28. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above findings give the diagnosis of respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: pH is reduced (7.12), hence acidosis.

Step 2: Since pCO2 is raised (50 mmHg), it is respiratory acidosis.

Step 3: HCO3 is raised (28 mEq/L) suggesting there is metabolic compensation.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: Identify the type of flap.
questions.solution:
The picture shows a radial forearm free flap. In a free flap the blood supply is isolated, disconnected and then reconnected using micosurgery at the new site. Other eg: DIEP (Deep inferior epigastric perforators) flap, free fibular flap

  • A random flap include three sides of a rectangle, bearing no specific relationship to where the blood supply enters.Eg:V-Y plasty, Z plasty, Limberg or rhomboid flap.
  • Axial flap is much longer and is based on known blood vessels. Eg: Latissmus dorsi flap,TRAM (Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous) flap
  • Islanded flap are those in which the axial blood supply is swung round on a stalk.

Note:

Flap defines the tongue of tissue; pedicle is used to describe the base or stem with the vascular supply.

Skin-bearing flaps are classified according to three basic characteristics—

  • Composition: refers to the tissue contained within the flap, such as cutaneous, musculocutaneous, fasciocutaneous etc
  • Method of movement:
    • Local transfer, eg. advancement or rotation flaps
    • Distant transfer, eg. pedicle flaps from the abdomen to the perineum or micro-vascular free flaps.
  • Blood supply
    • Musculocutaneous arteries travel perpendicularly through muscle to the overlying skin.
    • Septocutaneous arteries travel with intermuscular fascial septa to supply the overlying skin.

questions.text: Which of the following parts of bones are not prone to avascular necrosis?
questions.solution:
Head of the femur is prone to avascular necrosis and not the neck of femur.

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of hip
  • Body of talus in fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of scaphoid in fracture through the waist of the scaphoid

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen in the fracture of neck of talus. Presence of this sign indicates that blood supply to the talus is adequate.

questions.text: While performing a PET-CT scan, uptake in which of the following areas is likely to be a false positive?
questions.solution:
On 18F-FDG PET-CT scan, the urinary bladder shows normal physiological uptake and is a potential source of false-positive in oncologic imaging. 

The following are areas of normal physiological uptake on PET CT:

  • Brain tissue
  • Skeletal muscle, especially after strenuous activity and laryngeal muscles following speech
  • Myocardium
  • Gastrointestinal tract - intestinal wall
  • Genitourinary tract - as FDG is excreted via the renal system and passes into the collecting systems
  • Brown fat - FDG accumulates here as glucose and ATP are required for heat production
  • Thymus
  • Bone marrow

The following image shows supraclavicular uptake on a PET scan, due to the presence of brown adipose tissue.
